A hands-on guide to grasping the moon's schedule on this special day, honored on Friday, October 10, 2025.
The moon's late rise on Karwa Chauth is no accident but part of a cosmic rhythm. Its timing aligns with its orbital path, position in the sky, and Earth's location.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha). Since it’s just four days after the full moon, moonrise happens later in the evening.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later each day. By the fourth day of its waning phase, this delay becomes noticeable, making moonrise much later than it was on the full moon night.
Your exact position on Earth—latitude and longitude—dictates when the moon rises, causing times to vary by location.
